Ryan is a longtime limited grinder & competitive player who recently qualified for the World Championships by getting 2nd place at Arena Championship 5. They are a regular on the 17Lands leaderboards and in the Day 2 draft queues at Arena Opens. They write Magic strategy articles at https://www.patreon.com/ryancmtg.

How to Build a Sealed Deck

It's time to talk about my favorite limited format.

That's right! I'm a Sealed Enjoyer. Unsurprising given my love for limited, but most limited players prefer draft. It takes a true sicko to love the format where you get what you get and you don't get upset!

"Sealed is the lottery"

"Once I see my rares I know if I have a chance"

"I lost to double Bonny Pall, nothing I could do. What a dumb format"

"My pool is unplayable, I should probably just drop"

"Why do they even have Sealed tournaments, all it tests is your pack opening skill"

You get it. You've heard it. You've experienced it. I certainly have. Sealed is the Magic format where the injustice, the inequality, the pure LUCK of it all is front and center. Some people are just going to have better decks than you, and there's nothing you can do about it.

And yet...

Have you ever checked the "traditional sealed" leaderboards on 17Lands? The players there have higher winrates than the bo3 drafters. Huh.

Have you ever noticed how you see pros at the top tables of sealed tournaments time and time again? How Martin Juza and Shuhei Nakamura dominated Sealed Grand Prixs with ease?

The evidence is hard to argue with if you really pay attention to it. Sealed is just as skill testing as draft. Why?

Combinatorics The answer is that large numbers scale much faster than small numbers when it comes to the ways in which they combine.

In a draft, you're going to end up with 42 cards in your pool, each selected from a pack of 14 or less. That's a lot of decisions! It might seem like there are far more decisions in draft than in sealed. After all, you literally see more cards!

Choosing 23 cards out of a static 84 might seem easy in comparison. What's the math on that, anyway?

Oh. uhhh..... that's... that's not a small number. Google's calculator needs to display it to me in scientific notation.

Just for comparison, what would a rough way to estimate the number of decisions in draft look like?

Look, that's a lot of decisions. But it's no Sealed.

Testing Skill Obviously, this is not a perfect way to evaluate which format is more difficult or more rewarding of skill. But hopefully it's a nudge for our intuitions away from the idea that draft is more decision-intense by nature. If the math checks out, and top players consistently win at sealed at similar or even greater rates to draft, something must be going on here.

What skills does Sealed test?

I think Sealed is the purest test of deckbuilding there is in Magic. Rather than knowing the top decks in advance and being able to test against them like in constructed, and instead of having your decisions presented to you one card at a time like in draft, Sealed is all about building the best possible machine with what you've already got.

In lots of ways, it's Magic as Garfield intended -- players are essentially opening "starter packs", mini collections from which they will build their one "Magic deck".

Sealed requires innovation and improvisation, as well as adaptability to any situation. This goes beyond the deckbuilding portion -- Sealed is the only format in Magic where you have a large enough sideboard to completely remake your deck in between games.

I won't be focusing too much on sideboarding in this guide -- This is mainly intended to be a guide to building a pool "blind" at the start of a tournament. But many of the skills are transferable - If you understand what makes a deck strong against "the field", you should understand how to adjust it to a particular matchup (or in rare cases, pivot entirely).

Getting started It would be difficult to go through all the stages of building a sealed pool in the abstract without having a specific example to work from, so we're going to be following along with a recent example I selected because it happened to be a particularly interesting build. Here it is! You can take a few minutes to try and build it yourself, then compare what your process looked like to mine, or follow along step-by-step as we go -- it's up to you! I think either method will work well. All I'll ask is for you to seriously engage with how you'd be thinking through this pool, and comparing your views to mine. I think this is a pool with a lot of nuance, and I don't think there's a clear right answer here, so it's less about the answers and more about the thought processes.

https://sealeddeck.tech/22cEndg8Ui

Let's get into it!
